'''Post-racial United States''' is a theoretical environment in which the [[United States]] is free from [[Racism|racial preference]], [[discrimination]], and [[prejudice]].
== Origins of the term == One of the earliest uses of the term "post-racial" to describe the United States was in an October 5, 1971, article in ''[[The New York Times]]'' titled "Compact Set Up for 'Post-Racial' South".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1971/10/05/79156105.pdf|work = The New York Times|last = Wootens|first = James T.|date = October 5, 1971|title = Compact Set Up for 'Post-Racial' South|access-date = January 2, 2016|via = }}</ref> The article reported the establishment of a "Southern Growth Policies Board" in [[Durham, North Carolina]], "by some 70 politicians and professors who believe their region of 60 million citizens has entered an era in which race relations are soon to be replaced as a major concern by population increase, industrial development, and economic fluctuations".<ref name=":2" />
==2008 Presidential election== [[File:BarackObamaportrait.jpg|thumb|President Barack Obama|225x225px]] Some Americans saw the presidential candidacy of [[Barack Obama]], and his [[United States presidential election, 2008|election in 2008]] as the first [[Black people|black]] [[president of the United States]], as a sign that the nation had, in fact, become post-racial.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A New, 'Post-Racial' Political Era in America|url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18489466|website = NPR.org|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/10347165|title = One Year Later and the Myth of a Post-Racial Society|last = Dawson|first = Michael C.|date = 2009|journal = Du Bois Review|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 2016-01-01|last2 = Bobo|first2 = Lawrence D.}}</ref> The [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] radio host [[Lou Dobbs]], for example, said in November 2009, "We are now in a 21st-century post-partisan, post-racial society."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Dobbs calls on listeners to rise above "partisan and racial element that dominates politics"|url = http://mediamatters.org/video/2009/11/12/dobbs-calls-on-listeners-to-rise-above-partisan/156917|website = Media Matters for America|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> Two months later, [[Chris Matthews]], an [[MSNBC]] host, said of President Obama, "He is post-racial by all appearances. You know, I forgot he was black tonight for an hour."<ref>{{Cite web|title = MSNBC's Matthews On Obama: "I Forgot He Was Black Tonight" {{!}} RealClearPolitics|url = http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2010/01/27/msnbcs_matthews_on_obama_i_forgot_he_was_black_tonight.html|website = www.realclearpolitics.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref>
However, public opinion on whether the United States is post-racial is itself divided starkly by race. In a [[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]/[[ABC News]] poll conducted in December 2014, about 50% of white respondents said they believed that the justice system treats Americans of all races equally, but only 10% of African-Americans said the same.<ref>{{Cite news|title = On racial issues, America is divided both black and white and red and blue|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/on-racial-issues-america-is-divided-both-black-and-white-and-red-and-blue/2014/12/26/3d2964c8-8d12-11e4-a085-34e9b9f09a58_story.html?hpid=z4|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2014-12-26|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0190-8286|language = en-US|first = Dan|last = Balz|first2 = Scott|last2 = Clement}}</ref> In the spring of 2015, according to a [[Gallup (company)|Gallup]] poll, 13 percent of black Americans surveyed identified race relations as the most important problem the United States faces, compared with 4 percent of white Americans.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Views of Race Relations as Top Problem Still Differ by Race|url = http://www.gallup.com/poll/183572/race-divides-views-race-relations-top-problem.aspx|website = Gallup.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref>
Arguments that the United States is ''not'' post-racial frequently emphasize the treatment of African-Americans and other racial minorities in the criminal justice system and in interactions with the police. Killings of unarmed African-Americans, [[List of killings by law enforcement officers in the United States|often by police officers]], have been widely publicized. In 2015, according to a study by ''[[The Guardian]]'', police officers in the United States killed 7.13 black Americans per million, compared with 2.91 white Americans per million.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Counted: people killed by police in the United States in 2015 – interactive|url = https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2015/jun/01/the-counted-police-killings-us-database|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> Additionally:
{{quote|Young black men were nine times more likely than other Americans to be killed by police officers in 2015, according to the findings of a Guardian study that recorded a final tally of 1,134 deaths at the hands of law enforcement officers this year.
Despite making up only 2% of the total US population, African American males between the ages of 15 and 34 comprised more than 15% of all deaths logged this year by an ongoing investigation into the use of deadly force by police. Their rate of police-involved deaths was five times higher than for white men of the same age.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Young black men killed by US police at highest rate in year of 1,134 deaths|url = https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/31/the-counted-police-killings-2015-young-black-men|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2016-01-02|first = Jon|last = Swaine|first2 = Oliver|last2 = Laughl|first3 = Jamiles|last3 = Lartey|first4 = Ciara|last4 = McCarthy}}</ref>}}
Such killings had a marked effect on public perceptions of [[Racism in the United States|race relations in America]]. The 13 percent of black Americans who called race relations the most pressing problem in the United States in the spring 2015 Gallup poll dwarfed the 3 percent that Gallup reported at the beginning of 2014.<ref name=":3" /> And the percentage of white Americans who said race relations were the most important issue rose to 4 percent in 2015 from 1 percent in 2014.<ref name=":3" />
In response to high-profile incidents such as the fatal shootings of [[Shooting of Michael Brown|Michael Brown]], [[Death of Aiyana Jones|Aiyana Jones]], [[Shooting of Trayvon Martin|Trayvon Martin]], [[Shooting of Laquan McDonald|Laquan McDonald]], [[Shooting of Tamir Rice|Tamir Rice]], and [[Shooting of Walter Scott|Walter Scott]], and the death of [[Death of Freddie Gray|Freddie Gray]] from a spinal-cord injury sustained in police custody, academics<ref name=":0" /> and journalists<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = There Is No Post-Racial America|url = https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2015/07/post-racial-society-distant-dream/395255/|website = The Atlantic|publisher = |accessdate = 2016-01-02|language = en-US}}</ref> have denounced claims that America is post-racial. [[Ta-Nehisi Coates]] wrote in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' in 2015 that the phrase "post-racial" was "usually employed by talk-show hosts and news anchors looking to measure progress in the Obama era."<ref name=":1" /> And [[Anna Holmes]] wrote in ''The New York Times'', "Chattel slavery and the legacies it left behind continue to shape American society. Sometimes it seems as if the desire for a 'post-racial' America is an attempt by white people to liberate themselves from the burden of having to deal with that legacy."<ref>{{Cite news|title = America's 'Postracial' Fantasy|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/05/magazine/americas-postracial-fantasy.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-06-30|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = Anna|last = Holmes}}</ref>[[File:Black Lives Matter Black Friday (15305650544).jpg|thumb|[[Black Lives Matter]] protester|left]] However, others argue that post-racial politics champions aggressive action to deliver economic opportunity and weed out police misconduct, without the divisive framing of racial identity. Under this view, there is no claim that America has attained a fully post-racial society, however it is argued that news selection is skewed toward amplifying racial conflict, events demonstrating racial harmony are dismissed as non-newsworthy, and that such media conflict-bias acts to undermine trust and impede progress. Rather, any true measure of race relations must gauge the everyday daily experiences of Americans in interacting with people of differing backgrounds. An assumption is that the media will cherry-pick the most outrageous, racially-inflammatory events to cover no matter how infrequently they are occurring, and thus misreport progress toward a post-racial ideal. The central tenet of post-racial problem-solving practice is to seek the "alternative explanation" when conflict arises (presuming non-racist motives in others), in order to find common ground and creatively resolve the conflict. Examples of post-racial framing in attacking misconduct by the Criminal Justice System are video recording of all police-citizen interactions, creating a Citizens Review Board with investigative powers, and assigning an independent prosecutor. Or, in the educational sphere, creating charters, academies and school choice to turn around under-performing schools. The divide in public opinion on the status of race in America was reflected in reactions to the [[Black Lives Matter|Black Lives Matter movement]]. In response to the "black lives matter" rallying cry, some people, including politicians, began using the phrase "all lives matter".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hillary Clinton's 'All Lives Matter' Remark Stirs Backlash|url = https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/06/24/hillary-clintons-all-lives-matter-remark-stirs-backlash/|website = The New York Times - First Draft|date = 2015-06-24|accessdate = 2016-01-02|first = Alan|last = Rappeport}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Law Enforcement and the Communities We Serve: Bending the Lines Toward Safety and Justice|url = https://www.fbi.gov/news/speeches/law-enforcement-and-the-communities-we-serve-bending-the-lines-toward-safety-and-justice|website = FBI|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Huckabee Says Civil Rights Icon Dr. King Would Be 'Appalled' By Black Lives Matter Movement|url = http://thinkprogress.org/election/2015/08/19/3692954/huckabee-black-lives-matter-mlk/|website = ThinkProgress|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> After a sheriff's deputy in [[Harris County, Texas]], was fatally shot while pumping gas in August,<ref>{{Cite news|title = Texas: Sheriff's Deputy Is Fatally Shot at Gas Station|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/29/us/texas-sheriffs-deputy-is-fatally-shot-at-gas-station.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-08-29|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = David|last = Montgomery}}</ref> Sheriff Ron Hickman claimed that the rhetoric of Black Lives Matter activists had contributed to the killing and said, "We've heard 'black lives matter'. All lives matter. Well, cops' lives matter, too. So why don't we just drop the qualifier and just say 'lives matter', and take that to the bank.'<ref>{{Cite news|title = Texas Deputy Killed 'Because He Wore a Uniform,' Sheriff Says|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/us/shooting-of-texas-deputy-is-called-coldblooded-execution.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-08-29|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = Manny|last = Fernandez|first2 = David|last2 = Montgomery}}</ref> [[File:Racial Divide Detroit MI.png|thumb|[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]: Caucasians in red, African-Americans in blue, Hispanics in orange, and Asians in green. A dot represents 25 people.|200x200px]]Supporters of the Black Lives Matter movement criticized the "all lives matter" phrase, arguing that it minimized the systemic threats faced by African-Americans.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Rep. Ellison: 'When You Say All Lives Matter - You Are Ignoring…American Racism'|url = http://cnsnews.com/news/article/eric-scheiner/rep-ellison-when-you-say-all-lives-matter-you-are-ignoring-american|website = CNS News|accessdate = 2016-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = What's the Matter with 'All Lives Matter'|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-bedrick/whats-the-matter-with-all-lives-matter_b_7922482.html|website = The Huffington Post|accessdate = 2016-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = 'All lives matter' is and always was racist – the weekend's campaign rally proved it {{!}} Dave Bry|url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/nov/23/all-lives-matter-racist-trump-weekend-campaign-rally-proved-it|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2016-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Problem with Saying 'All Lives Matter'|url = http://www.relevantmagazine.com/current/nation/problem-saying-all-lives-matter|website = RELEVANT Magazine|publisher = |accessdate = 2016-01-03}}</ref> President Obama said in October, "There is a specific problem that is happening in the African-American community that's not happening in other communities."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Obama Explains The Problem With 'All Lives Matter'|url = http://thinkprogress.org/justice/2015/10/22/3715332/obama-explains-the-problem-with-all-lives-matter/|website = ThinkProgress|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> [[Andrew Rosenthal]] wrote, similarly, in ''The New York Times'', "The point of 'Black Lives Matter' is that the lives of African-Americans have come under special and deadly threat since before the birth of this country."<ref>{{Cite web|title = Mike Huckabee Misses the Point of Black Lives Matter|url = http://takingnote.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/19/mike-huckabee-misses-the-point-of-black-lives-matter/|website = Taking Note|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref>
Evidence of continued racial divisions in the United States can also be found in [[Demography|demographics]]. For instance, African-Americans account for less than 15 percent of the total population of [[Michigan]], but more than 82 percent of the population of the state's largest city, [[Detroit]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Detroit, MI Population by Race and Ethnicity - CLRSearch|url = http://www.clrsearch.com/Detroit-Demographics/MI/Population-by-Race-and-Ethnicity|website = CLRSearch|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> — and Detroit, like many cities whose residents are predominantly black, has "resegregated schools, dwindling tax bases and decaying public services".<ref>{{Cite news|title = A Dream Still Deferred|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/27/opinion/27Sugrue.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2011-03-26|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = Thomas J.|last = Sugrue}}</ref>
There is a similar dynamic in [[Louisiana]]; the state was about 64 percent white as of the 2010 Census,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Louisiana QuickFacts from the US Census Bureau|url = http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/22000.html|website = quickfacts.census.gov|accessdate = 2016-01-02|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140119205316/http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/22000.html|archivedate = 2014-01-19|df = }}</ref> but its largest city, [[New Orleans]], is 60 percent black.<ref>{{Cite web|title = New Orleans (city) QuickFacts from the US Census Bureau|url = http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/22/2255000.html|website = quickfacts.census.gov|accessdate = 2016-01-02|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160102053100/http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/22/2255000.html|archivedate = 2016-01-02|df = }}</ref> Further segregation can be found within New Orleans: the [[Lower Ninth Ward]], for example, is 97 percent black.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lower 9th Ward, New Orleans, LA Population & Demographics|url = http://www.areavibes.com/new+orleans-la/lower+9th+ward/demographics/|website = www.areavibes.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> This was the neighborhood that experienced the most catastrophic flooding after [[Hurricane Katrina]], and the government's [[Criticism of government response to Hurricane Katrina|response to the disaster]] has been cited as evidence of the continued presence of racism in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Race An Issue In Katrina Response|url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/race-an-issue-in-katrina-response/|website = www.cbsnews.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Katrina victims blame racism for slow aid|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/id/10354221/ns/us_news-katrina_the_long_road_back/t/katrina-victims-blame-racism-slow-aid/|website = msnbc.com|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> Most of the victims were black and poor, and class was a major factor in who survived: Those who lived in areas better protected from flooding, and those who were able to evacuate before the storm, tended to be wealthier.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hurricane Katrina: The Race and Class Debate|url = http://monthlyreview.org/2006/07/01/hurricane-katrina-the-race-and-class-debate/|website = Monthly Review|accessdate = 2016-01-02|first = Kristen|last = Lavelle|date = 2006}}</ref> At the time, President [[George W. Bush]] acknowledged that this poverty had "roots in the history of racial discrimination, which cut off generations from the opportunities of America".<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bush Calls for Bold Plan to Rebuild Coast|url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4850527|website = NPR.org|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref>
== Political implications == The idea that America is post-racial, or close to it, has played a role in at least one [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] decision. In ''[[Shelby County v. Holder]]'' in 2013, the court invalidated a section of the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]] that had required nine states with particularly severe histories of racial discrimination to obtain federal approval for any change to their election laws.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Supreme Court Invalidates Key Part of Voting Rights Act|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/26/us/supreme-court-ruling.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2013-06-25|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = Adam|last = Liptak}}</ref> The ruling, written by Chief Justice [[John Roberts|John G. Roberts Jr.]], said in part, "Our country has changed." It added that in the decades since the Voting Rights Act was passed, "voting tests were abolished, disparities in voter registration and turnout due to race were erased, and African-Americans attained political office in record numbers. And yet the coverage formula that Congress reauthorized in 2006 ignores these developments, keeping the focus on decades-old data relevant to decades-old problems, rather than current data reflecting current needs."<ref>''[https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/12pdf/12-96_6k47.pdf Shelby County v. Holder]'', 570 U. S. ___ (2013). Retrieved 2016-01-02.</ref> Similar issues are involved<ref>{{Cite web|title = A Colorblind Constitution: What Abigail Fisher's Affirmative Action Case Is Really About|url = https://www.propublica.org/article/a-colorblind-constitution-what-abigail-fishers-affirmative-action-case-is-r|website = ProPublica|accessdate = 2016-01-02}}</ref> in ''[[Fisher v. University of Texas (2016)|Fisher v. University of Texas]]'', a challenge to [[Affirmative action in the United States|affirmative action]] policies on which the court is expected to rule in 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Supreme Court Justices' Comments Don't Bode Well for Affirmative Action|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/10/us/politics/supreme-court-to-revisit-case-that-may-alter-affirmative-action.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-12-09|access-date = 2016-01-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = Adam|last = Liptak}}</ref>

{{Infobox television| |show_name = Prom Queen |image = |runtime = 90 seconds |creator = [[Big Fantastic]] (Doug Cheney, Chris Hampel, Chris McCaleb, Ryan Wise) |producer = [[Vuguru]] |director = Doug Cheney, Chris Hampel, Chris McCaleb, Ryan Wise |starring = |country = [[Image:Flag of the United States.svg|15px]] [[United States]] |filmed = |network = [[MySpace]]
[[YouTube]]
[[Veoh]] |related = [[SamHas7Friends]] |first_aired = April 1, 2007 |last_aired = present |num_episodes = 80 |website = http://www.promqueen.tv/}} '''''Prom Queen''''' is the first [[web television]] series produced by former [[Walt Disney]] CEO [[Michael Eisner]]'s new production company [[Vuguru]] and veteran web television production company [[Big Fantastic]], the creators of ''[[Sam Has 7 Friends]]''. The series, consisting of 80 episodes of 90 seconds each, is one of the best-funded entrants into the world of original programming designed exclusively for online video.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2007/03/72976|title=Meet Michael Eisner's Prom Date|date=2007-03-15|work=[[Wired Magazine]]}} The show generated revenue through sponsorships, by selling some of the clothing worn by the characters, and by carrying advertising for ''[[Hairspray (2007 film)|Hairspray]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.redherring.com/Article.aspx?a=21681&hed=Eisner%E2%80%99s+Indie+Gamble§or=Industries&subsector=InternetAnd|title=Eisner’s Indie Gamble|date=2007-03-18|work=[[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring]]}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The series premiered April 1, 2007 on [[MySpace]], and supplemental scenes can be seen on MySpace as each of the characters has a MySpace page that includes [[blog]]s, [[Video clip|Vlogs]], and comments between the characters. According to the ''[[Financial Times]]'', it marks MySpace's boldest push into original video content. The series was also distributed on [[YouTube]], [[Veoh]], and on an original Prom Queen website.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2153e480-dd8e-11db-8d42-000b5df10621.html|title=MySpace, Eisner in online video deal|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=2007-03-29}} The first season ended on June 20, 2007, with over 15 million views of the episodes during the original 12-week run,{{Cite news|url=http://www.blinkx.com/article/blinkx-distribute-prom-queen-summer-heat-spinoff-series~453|title=blinkx.com to Distribute "Prom Queen: Summer Heat," the Spinoff Series of Emmy-Nominated Broadband Drama, "Prom Queen"|date=2007-08-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221033531/http://www.blinkx.com/article/blinkx-distribute-prom-queen-summer-heat-spinoff-series~453|archivedate=2009-02-21|df=}} and has been viewed by over 40 million people to date.{{Cite news|url=http://tbivision.com/news/2012/10/the-cw-picks-up-vurugus-digital-series-prom-queen/18480/|title=The CW picks up Vurugu’s digital series Prom Queen|date=2012-10-18|work=Television Business International|first=Peter|last=White}} A 15-episode spinoff series, ''[[Prom Queen: Summer Heat]]'', debuted on August 27, 2007. On May 7, 2008, a Japanese remake of the series, titled ''Tokyo Prom Queen'', began airing in a similar format. On October 20, 2008, Michael Eisner confirmed that a third season of "Prom Queen" would be produced.{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldscreen.com/interviewscurrent.php?filename=eisner1008.htm|title=Michael Eisner|date=2008-10-20|accessdate=2008-10-20}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} A DVD of the series was released on October 8, 2008; it included behind-the-scenes footage and audio commentaries from the cast and creators of the series. In July 2009 it was announced that a follow-up series was being filmed, entitled ''Prom Queen: The Homecoming''. Starting July 4, 2010, 'Homecoming' began to air on [[Citytv]], a Canada-based television website. Four episodes were released each Monday. "Homecoming" connected 'Sam Has 7 friends' with 'Prom Queen' and primarily focused on the character, Sadie Simmons. 'Homecoming' ended with a cliffhanger, suggesting another season would appear. In October 2012, "Homecoming" debuted in the United States (along with the original "Prom Queen" and "Sam Has 7 Friends") on [[The CW Television Network|The CW]]'s website.{{Cite news| url = http://www.zimbio.com/TV+News/articles/5OeWZrZrGJL/Popular+Web+Series+Prom+Queen+Sam+7+Friends | title = Popular Web Series 'Prom Queen' and 'Sam Has 7 Friends' Hit the CW Website | author = Jill Slattery | work = [[Zimbio]] | date = 2012-10-15}} As of November 2014, the first season can be seen for free on YOUTUBE, at the channel promqueentv. The episodes contain their original edits, without being pasted together as they had been on THE CW website. ==Plot== The core plot of ''Prom Queen'' revolves around a text message sent to Ben, saying "U R going 2 kill the prom queen." This occurs as the prom approaches, and the drama begins to unfold. ==Main characters== *Ben - the witty student who receives a cryptic message. *Sadie - Ben's quiet sister, who writes for the school newspaper. She says she hates the idea of prom, but secretly wants to attend. *Chad - the school jock, who carries a pink phone that receives a call from one person only. Who could it be? *Nikki - Chad's girlfriend. She's stuck-up and wants to be the prom queen. However, she has a terrible self-image and has a secret. *Lauren - Nikki's friend who has a bad relationship with her mother. She loves Josh, but does he love her? *Curtis - Sadie's quirky best friend with possible other agendas. *Jill - Lauren's mother, who was Prom Queen at her prom. Jill is mentally unhealthy and seems to be obsessed with Ben. *Danica - a British exchange student, staying with Lauren; she has a video camera which she uses daily, to capture her American experience. *Courtney - the girl whom Ben likes. They are doing a school play together, but it seems she has a second life, of sorts. *Josh - Ben's friend, who keeps to himself and is even a mystery to Ben. ==Cast== *[[Sean Hankinson]] - Ben *[[Katy Stoll]] - Sadie *David Loren - Chad *Laura Howard - Danica *Alexandra French - Nikki *Jake Shideler - Josh *Haley Mancini - Lauren *John Shires - Nolan *Mills Allison - Curtis *Andre Boyer - Brett *[[Sheila Vand]] - Courtney *Kateland Carr - Michele *Amy Kay Raymond - Jill ==Music== James McKeever wrote the musical score for the series. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.promqueen.tv/ promqueen.tv] - official site *{{IMDb title|1002670|Prom Queen}} *[http://www.myspace.com/promqueentv Official Prom Queen account] on [[MySpace]] *[http://promqueen.imeem.com/ Prom Queen profile] on [[imeem]] {{Tornante company}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prom Queen (Web Series)}} [[Category:2007 web series debuts]] [[Category:Drama web series]] [[Category:American web series]] [[Category:Proms in fiction]]

[[File:Donetsk hanuka.jpg|150px|thumb|right|A public [[Menorah (Hanukkah)|Hanukkah menorah]] in [[Donetsk]], [[Ukraine]].]] A '''public menorah''' is a large [[Menorah (Hanukkah)|menorah]] displayed publicly during the [[Jewish holiday]] of [[Hanukkah]]. It is done to celebrate the holiday and publicize the [[Hanukkah#Traditional view|miracle of Hanukkah]], and is typically accompanied by a public event during one of the nights of Hanukkah attended by invited dignitaries who are honored with lighting the menorah.<ref name="Largest Menorah">{{cite news|url=http://journalism.nyu.edu/pubzone/livewire/archived/the_worlds_largest_menorah/|title=The World's Largest Menorah|last=Lernar|first=Dana|publisher=NYU Jurnalism Institute|accessdate=21 December 2009|location=[[New York City]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113034858/http://journalism.nyu.edu/pubzone/livewire/archived/the_worlds_largest_menorah/|archivedate=13 November 2009|df=}}</ref>
Public menorah lighting were initiated by Rabbi [[Menachem M. Schneerson]] in 1974. The most prominent public menorah celebration takes place in Washington DC, and is known as the [[National Menorah]]. In 2013 Chabad planned 15,000 public menorah lighting events across the globe.
==History== The concept of lighting a [[Menorah (Temple)|menorah]] in a way that allows the public to see it dates back to ancient times, where menorahs were lit outside of people's homes in order to publicize the miracle of Hanukkah. The concept of lighting a large menorah in public was initiated by Rabbi [[Menachem M. Schneerson]], known as the Lubavitcher Rebbe.
In 1973 Rabbi Schneerson announced his Hanukkah-awareness campaign, encouraging his followers and emissaries to reach out to their fellow Jews and give them the opportunity to kindle the Hanukkah lights. That year they distributed some 60,000 tin menorahs.<ref>http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/18/menorah-medina/?_r=0</ref> In 1974, in continuation of Rabbi Schneerson's Hanukkah awareness campaign, when Rabbi [[Abraham Shemtov]] kindled a menorah at the foot of the Liberty Bell at Independence Hall.<ref>[http://joi.org/bloglinks/JTA%20NEWS%20Chanuka%20Chabad.htm ''Spreading like wildfire, but public menorah lightings still controversial'', JTA, December 5, 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006034939/http://joi.org/bloglinks/JTA%20NEWS%20Chanuka%20Chabad.htm |date=October 6, 2007 }}</ref> The following year, in 1975, rock promoter [[Bill Graham (promoter)|Bill Graham]] sponsored [[Chabad]]'s menorah in San Francisco.<ref>Fishkoff, Sue. "The Rebbe's Army, page 288</ref><ref name="San Francisco Menorah Lighting">{{cite news|url=http://www.sanfranciscosentinel.com/?p=18133/|title=FIRST LIGHTING OF HANUKKAH SUNDAY IN TRADITIONAL SAN FRANCISCO UNION SQUARE OBSERVANCE|last=Martinfield|first=Sean|publisher=San Francisco Sentinel|accessdate=5 January 2012|location=[[San Francisco|SF]]}}</ref>
Since 1974, the concept of public menorahs has expanded. In 1979, President [[Jimmy Carter]] participated in the lighting of the public menorah erected by Chabad. In 2013, Chabad planned 15,000 public menorah lighting events across the globe.<ref>Chabad.org [http://www.chabad.org/holidays/chanukah/article_cdo/aid/2406550/jewish/Chabad-Lubavitchs-Global-Chanukah-Campaign.htm "Chabad-Lubavitch's Global Chanukah Campaign"]</ref> And in 2014, the public menorah in [[Washington, D.C.]] was kindled by Vice President [[Joe Biden]].
Scholars have cited this initiative by Rabbi Schneerson as a prime factor in Hanukkah becoming such a widely celebrated festival.<ref>Joshua Eli Plaut, ''A Kosher Christmas: 'Tis the Season to be Jewish''. Rutgers University Press, 2012. Page 167.</ref><ref>Joseph Telushkin, ''[[Rebbe: The Life and Teachings of Menachem M. Schneerson, the Most Influential Rabbi in Modern History]]''. HarperCollins, 2014. Page 269.</ref><ref>Menachem Posner, [http://www.chabad.org/2778619/ 40 Years Later: How the Chanukah Menorah Made Its Way to the Public Sphere]. December 1, 2014.</ref>
==Notable Public Menorah Lightings==
===United States===
====White House National Menorah==== [[File:Carter Menorah.jpg|thumb|right|150px|US President [[Jimmy Carter]] attends Chabad's Menorah Lighting in [[Washington, D.C.]] in 1979]] {{Main|National Menorah}} Since 1979, the [[National Menorah]] has been lit on the [[White House]] grounds in celebration of Hanukkah. President [[Jimmy Carter]] attended that first ceremony, and President [[Ronald Reagan]] designated it the National Menorah.<ref name="WhiteHouseMenorah2012">{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2012/12/09/lighting-of-national-menorah-marks-the-beginning-of-hanukkah/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=12 December 2012 | title=Lighting of national menorah marks the beginning of Hanukkah|date=9 December 2012}}</ref> In 2009 the ceremony included then-White House [[Chief of Staff]] [[Rahm Emanuel]] (now mayor of Chicago),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/12/13/rahm-emanuel-lights-natio_n_390552.html|publisher=The Associated Press|accessdate=12 December 2012 | title=Rahm Emanuel Lights National Menorah At White House (PHOTOS)|date=13 December 2009}}</ref> followed by Chief of Staff [[Jack Lew]] in 2010 and 2011.<ref name="WhiteHouseMenorah2012"/> In 2012, the first candle was lit with the help of [[Jeffrey Zients]], director of the White House [[Office of Management and Budget]].<ref name="WhiteHouseMenorah2012"/>
====New York City==== The world's largest menorah stands at 32 feet and is lit at [[Fifth Avenue]] and 59th Street in [[Manhattan]] near [[Central Park]]. A 4,000-pound structure, it is the work of [[Israelis|Israeli]] artist [[Yaacov Agam]]. Because of the menorah's height, [[Consolidated Edison|Con Edison]] assists the lighting by using a [[Crane (machine)|crane]] to lift each person to the top. A [[Guinness World Record]] is pending.<ref name="Largest Menorah"/>
===United Kingdom===
====British Parliament==== Each year, the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom]] holds a menorah lighting at the home of the Speaker of the House of Commons. The menorah currently used was commissioned by the Rt. Hon. [[Michael Martin, Baron Martin of Springburn|Michael J. Martin]] MP, former Speaker of the House of Commons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mplevene.co.uk/staticpage.aspx?spageid=101480|title=M.P. Levene Special Commissions|accessdate=19 December 2009}}</ref>
====Trafalgar Square==== Since 2007, Chabad has organized a public menorah celebration at Trafalgar Square. Each year the event is sponsored by Chabad, the [[Jewish Leadership Council]], the [[London Jewish Forum]] and the mayor of London.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.london.gov.uk/get-involved/events/chanukah-in-the-square |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216020634/https://www.london.gov.uk/get-involved/events/chanukah-in-the-square |archivedate=2014-12-16 |df= }}</ref>
===Israel=== [[File:Hanukkah sign Nicosia Republic of Cyprus.JPG|thumb|right|Public Hanukkah menorah in [[Nicosia]], [[Cyprus]]]] Public menorahs are prominently displayed throughout Israel, notably in the [[Ben Gurion International Airport|Ben Gurion airport]]<ref>[http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/134929 Massive Chanukah Menorah will Greet Airborne Guests]</ref>
===Cyprus=== Each year Nicosia has lit a National Menorah in celebration of Hanukkah. [[Nicosia]] as the capital of the Republic of Cyprus has been the pioneer city to put a Menorah in its city center.
===Canada===
A large menorah is located at [[Toronto City Hall]] at the south east corner of [[Nathan Phillips Square]] during Hanukkah.<ref>http://www.torontograndprixtourist.com/2011/12/menorah-ready-at-city-hall.html</ref> as well as smaller one is also found at [[Old City Hall (Toronto)|Old City Hall]].<ref>http://www.torontograndprixtourist.com/2011/12/menorah-almost-ready-at-old-city-hall.html</ref>
==Controversy== [[Image:Chanukka Karlsruhe 1.jpg|thumb|A large [[Chabad]]-style menorah in front of the [[Karlsruhe Palace]] in [[Karlsruhe]], [[Germany]] before a public [[Chabad|Chabad-Lubavitch]] menorah lighting ceremony (2006).]]
The success of the public menorah campaign has not been without controversy. In 1988, the [[American Jewish Congress]] produced a 28-page report entitled "The Year of the Menorah", criticizing Chabad's public menorah campaign and the litigation that went with it. It complained of the increase in the number of menorahs placed on public lands, arguing that it was causing tension both within the community and with non-Jews.<ref>''Menorah displays stir Jewish rift'', Miami Herald, June 14, 1987</ref> In 1989, the [[ACLU]] challenged the legality of a display of a Chabad-owned public menorah in [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|County of Allegheny]]. In a court case [[County of Allegheny v. ACLU]] the [[United States Supreme Court]] ruled in favor of the menorah.
In 1989, the city of [[Burlington, Vermont]] denied the local Chabad chapter, headed by Rabbi Yitzchok Raskin permission to erect a menorah in the city's main park during Hanukkah.<ref>Mark A. Kaplan v. City of Burlington and Robert Whalen (12/12/89)United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, No. 89-7042; 891 F.2d 1024</ref> Raskin appealed the decision on two occasions after an initial hearing 1987 found the display to be unconstitutional under the [[Establishment Clause of the First Amendment]]. The ACLU assisted the City of Burlington in a final appeal in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] in 1991, and the menorah ban was upheld.<ref>Chabad-Lubavitch of Vermont v. City of Burlington, 936 F.2d 109 (C.A.2 (Vt.), 1991)</ref><ref>''New Twist to Old Fight: Menorah in Vermont Park'', Sally Johnson, New York Times, December 20, 1987</ref> There have been similar cases involving Chabad public menorahs with the courts ruling against Chabad, including [[Chicago]] (1990)<ref>Lubavitch Chabad House, Inc. v. City of Chicago, 917 F.2d 341 (C.A.7 (Ill.), 1990)</ref> [[Iowa]] (1986),<ref>Lubavitch of Iowa, Inc. v. Walters, 808 F.2d 656 (C.A.8 (Iowa), 1986),</ref> [[Cincinnati]] (1991),<ref>Congregation Lubavitch v. City of Cincinnati, 923 F.2d 458 (C.A.6 (Ohio), 1991)</ref> and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] (1991).<ref>Chabad-Lubavitch of Georgia v. Miller, 5 F.3d 1383 (C.A.11 (Ga.), 1993)</ref> In addition, in 1991, in [[White Plains, New York]], the [[City council|Common Council]] unanimously rejected the display of a Chabad menorah in a public space in the town with the support of many Jews, affirming a local tradition of keeping parks free of religious and political displays.<ref>''[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/nyregion/white-plains-council-blocks-electric-menorah-for-park.html?pagewanted=1 White Plains Council Blocks Electric Menorah for Park]'', Lisa W. Foderaro, [[New York Times]] December 3, 1991</ref>
On the other hand, in 2002, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed Rabbi Sholom B. Kalmanson of Chabad of [[Southern Ohio]] to light an 18-foot menorah in Cincinnati's [[Fountain Square, Cincinnati|Fountain Square]]. Justice [[John Paul Stevens]] upheld a lower court ruling that the city could not ban the menorah and other religious displays from the square.<ref>[http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/19399/edition_id/393/format/html/displaystory.html ''Supreme Court rules on public chanukiot'', Joe Berkofsky, Jewish Telegraphic Agency, December 6, 2002]</ref><ref>[http://law.onecle.com/ussc/537/537us1501.html Chabad Of Southern Ohio et al. v. City of Cincinnati, 537 U.S. 1501, (2002) (per curiam)]</ref>
Due to the menorah being a Jewish symbol, menorahs in public have been subject to [[anti-Semitic]] violence. For instance, in 2009 in [[Moldova]], a group of fundamentalist Orthodox Christians took down a public menorah and replaced it with a cross.<ref name="moldov">{{cite news |title=Moldovan Christians Tear Down Public Menorah |url=http://www.jewishtimes.com/index.php/jewishtimes/news/jt/international_news/moldovan_christians_tear_down_public_menorah/16116 |agency=JTA Wire Service|newspaper=[[Baltimore Jewish Times]] |publisher= |location=Budapest |accessdate=December 17, 2009 |date=December 17, 2009 }}</ref> The same year, in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]], a Chabad rabbi was attacked by a [[Muslim]] man while leading the candle lighting ceremony.<ref name="moldov" />
Controversy has also arisen at the Western Wall in Israel. For [[Hanukkah]] every year a giant menorah is erected in the men's section of the Western Wall and each night of the eight nights of the festival, male rabbis and male politicians are honored, while women are kept at a distance, where they are barely able to see the ceremony.<ref>"'Light One Candle with Women of the Wall' (Dec 11) Women of the Wall" {{cite web |url=http://womenofthewall.org.il/2014/12/light-one-candle/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304091022/http://womenofthewall.org.il/2014/12/light-one-candle/ |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> [[Women of the Wall]] sent a letter to Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] requesting a large menorah also be erected in the women's section, but Netanyahu simply forwarded the letter to Western Wall rabbi Shmuel Rabinowitz, who accused WoW of ulterior motives of trying to change the customs at the Wall. Responding to Rabinowitz' accusation, Anat Hoffman noted: "In his letter, Rabbi Rabinowitz speaks of bringing together and uniting the nation, and yet his actions exclude and discriminate against women as if women are not part of the same nation. Since he was chosen for this public position, Rabinowitz has never invited Women of the Wall or any other women to participate in the ceremonies or to be honored with the lighting of a candle at the Kotel on Hanukkah, despite the fact that women are obligated equally to men in this religious act." In December 2014 the personal menorahs the women brought to the Kotel were confiscated, but they were returned when police were called.<ref>"Maltz, Judy 'Rabbi bans Women of the Wall's Hanukkah candle-lighting ceremony' (Dec 14, 2014) Haaretz"http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/jewish-world-news/.premium-1.631730</ref><ref>"Judy Maltz 'Sarah Silverman joins Women activists at Western Wall Hanukkah ceremony: Kotel security confiscates prayer group's menorahs, returned only after complaint lodged with police.' (18 Dec 2014) Haaretz"http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/1.632612</ref>

[[File:EU 27 nations birth distribution by month 2000 to 2010.pdf|thumb|upright=1.2|The distribution of births according to month in the general population]][[File:Month of birth distribution UEFA youth tournaments 2010.pdf|thumb|upright=1.2|The distribution, according to month of birth, of players involved in UEFA organised international youth tournaments in 2010/11]]
The term '''relative age effect''' (RAE), also known as '''birthdate effect''' or '''birth date effect''', is used to describe a bias, evident in the upper echelons of youth sport<ref>http://repository.leedsmet.ac.uk/main/view_record.php?identifier=3720&SearchGroup=research{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref> and academia,<ref>http://www.cambridgeassessment.org.uk/images/109784-birthdate-effects-a-review-of-the-literature-from-1990-on.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref><ref>http://cee.lse.ac.uk/ceedps//ceedp93.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref> where participation is higher amongst those born early in the relevant selection period (and correspondingly lower amongst those born late in the selection period) than would be expected from the normalised distribution of live births. The selection period is usually the [[calendar year]], the [[academic year]] or the [[Season (sports)|sporting season]]. The difference in maturity - which can be extreme at young ages: a six-year old born in January is almost 17% older than a six-year old born in December in the same year<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://voxeu.org/article/relative-age-effect-over-long-term|title=Long-term relative age effect: Evidence from Italian football|website=VoxEU.org|access-date=2016-04-23}}</ref> - causes a performance gap that persists over time.
The term '''month of birth bias''' is also used to describe the effect and '''season of birth bias''' is used to describe similar effects driven by different hypothesised mechanisms.
The bias results from the common use of age related systems, for organizing youth sports competition and academic cohorts, based on specific cut-off dates to establish eligibility for inclusion. Typically a child born after the cut-off date is included in a cohort and a child born before the cut-off date is excluded from it.
== In sports == The most commonly used cut-off date for youth international sporting competition is 1 January. The [[IOC]]<ref>http://www.olympic.org/Documents/Reference_documents_Factsheets/The_Youth_Olympic_Games.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref> and [[FIFA]]<ref>https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/95/44/82/regulationsfu20wcturkey2013%5fee.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref> and the 6 international football confederations ([[Asian Football Confederation|AFC]], [[Confederation of African Football|CAF]], [[CONCACAF]], [[CONMEBOL]], [[Oceania Football Confederation|OFC]] and [[UEFA]]<ref>https://www.uefa.com/MultimediaFiles/Download/Regulations/competitions/Regulations/01/65/31/62/1653162_DOWNLOAD.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref>) all use 1 January as their administrative cut-off date when determining an athlete's eligibility to compete in youth competitions, children born before a specified cut-off date are excluded.
Malcolm Gladwell's book [[Outliers (book)|Outliers: The Story of Success]] and [[SuperFreakonomics]] by Steven Levitt and Stephen Dubner have popularised the issue in respect of Canadian ice-hockey players, European football players and US Major League baseball players.
The expected distribution of births in any given month across a population correlates closely to the number of days in the month, with February as the shortest month having the fewest births. The first graph shows the distribution of births, by month, for the [[European Union]] over the ten years from 2000 to 2009. There is a slight but clearly perceptible increase in the birth rate in the summer months.
A relative age effect is illustrated in the second graph by the month of birth distribution of over 4,000 youth players involved in the qualifying squads for U17, U19 and U21 tournaments organised by [[UEFA]] in 2010/11.
Research suggests that individuals born closer to the cut-off date are more likely to play professionally.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1123/ssj.16.1.54 |title=The Relative Age Effect in Soccer: Cross-Cultural Evidence for a Systematic Discrimination against Children Born Late in the Competition Year |journal=Sociology of Sport Journal |volume=16 |pages=54 |year=1999 |last1=Musch |first1=Jochen |last2=Hay |first2=Roy }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dukeorthopaedicjournal.com/mostdownloaded.aspx|title=The Duke Orthopaedic Journal - Jaypee Journals - Jaypee Brother|website=www.dukeorthopaedicjournal.com|access-date=2016-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.econlet.2011.11.009 |ssrn=1835304 |title=Returns to education in professional football |journal=Economics Letters |volume=114 |issue=3 |pages=326–8 |year=2012 |last1=Böheim |first1=René |last2=Lackner |first2=Mario }}</ref>
== In academia == Cut-off dates for academic cohort structuring, including the setting of [[Academic term|academic years]], are usually determined by national education authorities and tend to be based on autumn start dates, so August or September cut-off dates are common in the [[Northern Hemisphere]] and February or March cut-off dates are common in the [[Southern Hemisphere]]. This tendency reflects the historical need for children to be involved in summer-time agricultural work with school starting after harvesting.[[File:Oxford 10 years.png|thumb|upright=1.2|Oxford University RAE profile in aggregate 2004/5 to 2013/14]]A relative age effect in academia is illustrated in the third graph which shows the percent deviation from month of birth profile norms evident in graduations from Oxford University over a 10-year period. Academic relative age effects seem to be moderated by culture.<ref name="RADutch"/>
A 2006 study finds that relative age affects student performance and has long-lasting effects on life outcomes. The authors find that "the youngest members of each cohort score 4–12 percentiles lower than the oldest members in grade four and 2–9 percentiles lower in grade eight… data from Canada and the United States show that the youngest members of each cohort are even less likely to attend university."<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/qje/121.4.1437 |jstor=25098831 |title=The Persistence of Early Childhood Maturity: International Evidence of Long-Run Age Effects |journal=The Quarterly Journal of Economics |volume=121 |issue=4 |pages=1437–72 |year=2006 |last1=Bedard |first1=K |last2=Dhuey |first2=E }}</ref>
A 2014 study finds that Italian students born in the early months of the year "are more likely to be tracked in more academic schools rather than in vocational schools."<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jpolmod.2014.04.001 |title=The long-lasting effects of school entry age: Evidence from Italian students |journal=Journal of Policy Modeling |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=578–99 |year=2014 |last1=Ponzo |first1=Michela |last2=Scoppa |first2=Vincenzo }}</ref>
== In leadership positions == A relative age effect has also been observed in the context of leadership. Studies have found an over-representation of people born just after the school entry cut-off date in a range of leadership positions. Such an over-representation starts in high-school leadership activities such as sports team captain or club president.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.econedurev.2006.08.005 |title=What makes a leader? Relative age and high school leadership |journal=Economics of Education Review |volume=27 |issue=2 |pages=173–83 |year=2008 |last1=Dhuey |first1=Elizabeth |last2=Lipscomb |first2=Stephen }}</ref> In the adult life, this over-representation has been observed in top managerial positions (CEOs of S&P 500 companies),<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.econlet.2012.08.017 |title=The relative-age effect and career success: Evidence from corporate CEOs |journal=Economics Letters |volume=117 |issue=3 |pages=660–2 |year=2012 |last1=Du |first1=Qianqian |last2=Gao |first2=Huasheng |last3=Levi |first3=Maurice D }}</ref> and in top political positions, both in the USA (senators and representatives),<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/rssa.12154 |title=Born leaders: Political selection and the relative age effect in the US Congress |journal= Series A (Statistics in Society) |volume=179 |issue=3 |pages=809–29 |year=2016 |last1=Muller |first1=Daniel |last2=Page |first2=Lionel }}</ref> and in Finland (MPs).<ref>http://www.doria.fi/bitstream/handle/10024/148931/wp94.pdf?sequence=1{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref>
== In other spheres == Whilst an over-representation of early-born participation is evident in the aspirational fields of elite sport and education there is also evidence of a corresponding disproportionate over-representation of late-born children in [[Epidemiology|epidemiologically]] defined cohorts exhibiting conditions such as [[ADHD]],<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1503/cmaj.111619 |pmid=22392937 |pmc=3328520 |title=Influence of relative age on diagnosis and treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children |journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal |volume=184 |issue=7 |pages=755–62 |year=2012 |last1=Morrow |first1=R. L |last2=Garland |first2=E. J |last3=Wright |first3=J. M |last4=MacLure |first4=M |last5=Taylor |first5=S |last6=Dormuth |first6=C. R }}</ref> [[schizophrenia]]<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.schbul.a007030 |pmid=14609251 |title=A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Northern Hemisphere Season of Birth Studies in Schizophrenia |journal=Schizophrenia Bulletin |volume=29 |issue=3 |pages=587–93 |year=2003 |last1=Davies |first1=G |last2=Welham |first2=J |last3=Chant |first3=D |last4=Torrey |first4=E. F |last5=McGrath |first5=J }}</ref><ref>http://www.eduratio.be/raepolizzi.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref> and [[obesity]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2152/jmi.54.133 |pmid=17380024 |title=Correlation of month and season of birth with height, weight and degree of obesity of rural Japanese children |journal=The Journal of Medical Investigation |volume=54 |issue=1–2 |pages=133–9 |year=2007 |last1=Tanaka |first1=Hisako |last2=Sei |first2=Masako |last3=Quang Binh |first3=Tran |last4=Munakata |first4=Hokuma |last5=Yuasa |first5=Kyoko |last6=Nakahori |first6=Yutaka }}</ref> One study finds "that higher school starting age lowers the propensity to commit crime at young ages."<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/ecoj.12325 |ssrn=2984362 |title=School Starting Age and the Crime-age Profile |journal=The Economic Journal |volume=127 |issue=602 |pages=1096–118 |year=2017 |last1=Landersø |first1=Rasmus |last2=Nielsen |first2=Helena Skyt |last3=Simonsen |first3=Marianne }}</ref> However, other studies failed to replicate relative age effects on temperament, mood, or physical development.<ref name="RADutch">{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0128856 |pmid=26076384 |pmc=4468064 |title=Relative Age Effects in Dutch Adolescents: Concurrent and Prospective Analyses |journal=PLOS One |volume=10 |issue=6 |pages=e0128856 |year=2015 |last1=Jeronimus |first1=Bertus F |last2=Stavrakakis |first2=Nikolaos |last3=Veenstra |first3=René |last4=Oldehinkel |first4=Albertine J }}</ref>
==Lexicon== * '''[[wikt:ability grouping|Ability grouping]]''' – cohort selection by ability rather than chronological age. * '''Corrective Relative Age Adjustments''' – calculated adjustments to competitive outcomes designed to compensate for relative age advantage/disadvantage, for example by the re-calculation of sprint times according to relative age within a cohort.<ref name="Relative Age Effects in Athletic Sprinting and Corrective Adjustments as a Solution for Their Removal">{{cite journal | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0122988 | volume=10 | issue=4 | title=Relative Age Effects in Athletic Sprinting and Corrective Adjustments as a Solution for Their Removal | journal=PLOS One | pages=e0122988 | pmid=25844642 | pmc=4386815 | last1 = Romann | first1 = M | last2 = Cobley | first2 = S| year=2015 | bibcode=2015PLoSO..1022988R }}</ref> * '''Cut-off date''' – an administratively defined date in the calendar which determines the eligibility of individuals to be included in a cohort, usually a competition or an academic year group. A birth date prior to the cut-off date excludes an individual and a birth date after the cut-off date includes an individual. * '''Multi-age grouping''' – the broadening of cohort selection to encompass multiple chronological age groups. For example, a [[Multi-age classroom]]. * '''Relative Age Advantage''' – a competitive advantage accruing to an individual due to being born early in a selection period. A relative age advantage can also accrue to a group consisting of a majority of relatively older individuals.<ref name="socialproblemindex.med.ualberta.ca">http://www.socialproblemindex.med.ualberta.ca/RelAgeMinorHockeyCJBS.pdf{{full citation needed|date=July 2018}}</ref> * '''Relative Age Bias''' – a tendency towards the prioritised selection of relatively older members of a cohort. * '''Relative Age Characteristic''' (of an individual) – the quality of having been born early or late in the selection period. * '''Relative Age Competition''' – competition designed to avoid cut-off date rules, such as ‘average team age’ or ‘bio-banded’ competition. * '''Relative Age Disadvantage''' – a competitive disadvantage accruing to an individual due to being born late in a selection period. A relative age disadvantage can also accrue to a group consisting of a majority of relatively younger individuals.<ref name="socialproblemindex.med.ualberta.ca"/> * '''Relative Age Discrimination''' – indirect, systemic discrimination, disadvantaging relatively young individuals in a cohort and advantaging relatively old individuals in the same cohort. * '''Relative Age Effect''' – an observable '''effect''' resulting from a '''relationship''' between '''chronological age''' and an eligibility '''cut-off date''' used for cohort selection. * '''Relative Age Environment''' – the system of rules governing inclusion or exclusion from cohorts based on cut-off date eligibility rules. * '''Relative Age Quota''' – a quota system imposed on a cohort to establish an even distribution of chronological ages. * '''Relative Age Skew''' – statistically significant differing levels of participation observed amongst relatively older and relatively younger members of a cohort. * '''Selection Period''' – an administratively or culturally defined timeframe, such as a competition season or an academic year, established by reference to a cut-off date.

'''''Resident Evil 6''''', known in Japan as '''''Biohazard 6''''',{{efn|{{nihongo|''Biohazard 6''|バイオハザード6|Baiohazādo 6|lead=yes}}}} is a [[third-person shooter|third-person shooter game]] developed and published by [[Capcom]]. The ninth main game in the ''[[Resident Evil]]'' series, it was released for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] in October 2012 and for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] in March 2013. Players control [[Leon S. Kennedy]], [[Chris Redfield]], Jake Muller, and [[Ada Wong]], who confront the force behind a worldwide bio-terrorist attack; each character has unique abilities and styles.
''Resident Evil 6'' was conceptualized in 2009 and entered full development the following year under ''[[Resident Evil 4]]'' producer [[Hiroyuki Kobayashi (producer)|Hiroyuki Kobayashi]]. It had a development staff of more than 600, making it Capcom's largest production.
''Resident Evil 6'' received mixed reviews; some reviewers praised the game's storyline and themes, but the interwoven campaigns and departure from [[survival horror]] received criticism. With over 10 million copies sold, it is the third-bestselling Capcom game. It was rereleased for the [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] with all [[downloadable content]].
==Gameplay== [[File:RE6 Agent Hunt.jpg|thumb|left|250px|In this screenshot, a player assumes the role of a J'avo armed with a machete, whilst engaging another player playing as Sherry Birkin, in "Agent Hunt" mode.]]
''Resident Evil 6'' allows players to select between four scenarios with interwoven storylines.<ref name="kot1">{{cite web|last1=Totilo|first1=Stephen|title=17 Things About Resident Evil 6 That You Should Know|url=http://kotaku.com/5938032/17-things-about-resident-evil-6-that-you-should-know|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=9 May 2016|date=27 August 2012}}</ref> Each scenario follows one of four main protagonists: Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Jake Muller and Ada Wong. The player-characters from each scenario will have their own partners whom are controlled by either [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) or another player via local or online multiplayer. In addition, each scenario features a different play-style; for example, some player-characters are more vulnerable to attacks whereas others are more resilient.<ref name="gaydar1">{{cite web|last1=Houghton|first1=David|title=Resident Evil 6: 11 important changes that make it play unlike any Resident Evil you've seen before|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/resident-evil-6-11-important-changes-make-it-play-unlike-any-resident-evil-youve-played/|website=GamesRadar|publisher=Future plc|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=12 September 2012}}</ref> Each central character has unique abilities, which vary from increased reload times and carrying more ammunition.<ref name=kot1/> ''Resident Evil 6'' presents new innovations and gameplay mechanics such as rolling in any direction and running while shooting and sliding.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gilbert|first1=Ben|title=Resident Evil 6 to sport innovations like 'shooting whilst moving'|url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/02/15/resident-evil-6-to-sport-innovations-like-shooting-whilst-movin/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=15 February 2012}}</ref> The game also features a four-player co-operative mode.<ref name="euro1">{{cite web|last1=Matluef|first1=Jeffrey|title=Resident Evil 6 Preview: Fear of the Unknown|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-06-06-resident-evil-6-preview-fear-of-the-unknown|publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=6 June 2012}}</ref> When playing in single player mode, the player can allow another player to join in online at any time.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://ps3.ign.com/articles/121/1216844p1.html|title=Resident Evil 6: Chris Redfield and Leon Kennedy Playable|publisher=IGN|accessdate=11 April 2012|date=19 January 2012|author=George, Richard}}</ref> While performing certain actions, [[quick time events]] may occur, in which the player must follow onscreen prompts by pressing buttons or manipulating joysticks within a limited amount of time.<ref name=gaydar1/>
A new feature comes in the form of tablets; players may consume them in order to recover health, and more can be produced by mixing herbs.<ref name=kot1/> If one player runs out of health, that player will have a short time to try to defend themselves while their partners attempt to revive them. If any non-AI players are killed, gameplay will resume at the last checkpoint. The game features several primary enemies, including [[zombie]]s and the newly introduced J'avo. Unlike zombies, J'avo are able to interact with each other to plan an attack, use weapons, and heal themselves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andriasang.com/con0ny/re6_update/|title=Resident Evil 6: Zombies, J'avo and the C-Virus|publisher=Andriasang|accessdate=17 April 2012|author=Gatayat, Anoop}}</ref> Also some J'avo are susceptible to various mutations that increase their prowess in battle, the type of mutation sometimes depends on location of the injury. There are a total of 15 different mutations within the game.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jf4Ir-SD-nE|title=Resident Evil 6 E3 Demo - Chris|last=|first=|date=|website=Youtube|publisher=Resident Evil-Capcom|access-date=26 September 2016}}</ref> Certain enemies drop skill points when killed, which can be picked up and spent on upgrades such as increased weapon effectiveness or specific ammunition drops. The campaigns feature a "Lone Wolf" ability which allows the player to remove their artificial intelligence companion character.<ref>{{cite web|title=Resident Evil 6 Has An Unlockable "Lone Wolf" Ability|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/09/02/resident-evil-6-has-an-unlockable-lone-wolf-ability/|publisher=Siliconera|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=2 September 2012}}</ref> Players can equip three of these upgrades which apply to all campaigns.<ref>{{cite web|date=27 August 2012|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2012/08/27/resident-evil-6-the-war-on-bio-terror|title=Resident Evil 6: The War on Bio-Terror|author=Richard George|publisher=IGN|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> The game also features a stamina bar; which depletes once the player performs melee attacks, or uses a "quickshot" — which involves shooting a zombie with a headshot instantly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Resident Evil 6 Hands-On: Tension Through Resource Management|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2012/09/12/resident-evil-6-hands-on-tension-through-resource-management/|publisher=Siliconera|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=12 September 2012}}</ref> ''Resident Evil 6'' is twice as long as ''[[Resident Evil 5]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dutton|first1=Fred|title=Resident Evil 6 more than twice as long as RE5, says Capcom|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-06-18-resident-evil-6-more-than-twice-as-long-as-re5-says-capcom|publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=18 June 2012}}</ref>
The game features two new modes. "Mercenaries" mode involves players fighting for survival against hordes of enemies.<ref name=kot/>{{Failed verification|date=July 2016}} In the PC version, the Mercenaries mode features an exclusive sub-mode named "No Mercy", which involves the cast from ''[[Left 4 Dead 2]]'' fighting a total number of 300 enemies against a timer.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roberts|first1=Samuel|title=Now Playing: Merc mode in Resident Evil 6|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/now-playing-merc-mode-in-resident-evil-6/|publisher=PC Gamer|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=26 November 2014}}</ref> "Agent Hunt" mode allows players to take control of random enemies in other people's online sessions, however it is only unlocked after the player clears the three main campaigns. The longer the player stays in another online session, the more points they will earn.<ref name="kot">{{cite web|last1=Totilo|first1=Stpehen|title=The Coolest Part of Resident Evil 6|url=http://kotaku.com/5947915/the-coolest-part-of-resident-evil-6|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=9 May 2016|date=1 October 2012}}</ref>
==Plot==
On 24 December 2012, Jake Muller, son of late bio-terrorist [[Albert Wesker]], flees local authorities during a bio-terrorist attack. He partners with Division of Security Operations (DSO) agent and Raccoon City survivor [[Sherry Birkin]] and learns that she is to extract him from the country to create a vaccine for the new C-Virus. However, they are hunted by Ustanak, a hulking bio-weapon. Meanwhile, a Bio-terrorism Security Assessment Alliance (BSAA) strike team led by [[Chris Redfield]] and Piers Nivans is deployed to combat the infected local populace. However, they are attacked by the leader of Neo-Umbrella, who refers to herself as [[Ada Wong]]; she kills most of the BSAA members, using a device that injects them with the C-virus, turning them into monsters, except Chris and Piers. Chris goes into a self-imposed exile, afflicted with [[post-traumatic amnesia]]. Meanwhile, Sherry and Jake's extraction from Edonia by the BSAA is sabotaged, forcing them to crash into the mountains. They are captured by "Ada" for six months.
On 29 June 2013, US President Adam Benford attempts to publicly reveal the truth behind the 1998 Raccoon City incident and the government's dealings with Umbrella, to end further bio-terrorist activity. However, the venue is hit by another attack, infecting the President; the sole survivors, DSO agent and Raccoon City survivor [[Leon S. Kennedy]] and US Secret Service agent Helena Harper, are forced to kill him. The pair encounter the real Ada Wong, and Leon learns that National Security Advisor Derek Simmons is affiliated with Neo-Umbrella and was responsible for the attack. Leon and Helena pursue Simmons into Lanshiang, China, while faking their deaths. Meanwhile, Jake and Sherry escape captivity in Lanshiang.
Chris returns to duty in the BSAA with Piers and a new team, arriving in a besieged Lanshiang. Chris recovers from his amnesia and seeks revenge against Ada, resulting in casualties for his squad. Chris and Piers confront Ada, until Leon intervenes. After being informed by Leon, Chris and Piers pursue "Ada" to an aircraft carrier, destroying cruise missiles laden with the C-virus. Leon, Helena, Sherry, and Jake confront Simmons over his involvement with the outbreaks, where Sherry covertly hands Jake's medical data to Leon in case of their captivity. Leon and Helena corner Simmons, who has been infected by a J'avo, where he confesses to having killed the President to maintain national security. The two see off a mutated Simmons while Sherry and Jake are captured again. Attempting to leave the city, Leon and Helena are warned by Chris that a missile has been launched, but they are too late to stop it. Leon discloses Jake's real identity to Chris and has him rescue Jake and Sherry in a remote oil platform. With Ada's assistance, Leon and Helena kill Simmons.
On the oil platform, Chris and Piers head underground, freeing Jake and Sherry from captivity before preventing a large-scale attack by a gigantic bioweapon, Haos. Heavily wounded, and in a desperate attempt to save Chris, Piers injects himself with the C-virus to help turn the tide of the battle. He defeats Haos before evacuating. Aware that the mutation will worsen, Piers sacrifices himself by pushing Chris to an escape pod, using his abilities to destroy the base. Meanwhile, Jake and Sherry escape the facility and kill Ustanak as they ride a rocket-powered lift to the surface.
The imposter Ada was a scientist named Carla Radames, who was forced to transform into Ada by Simmons. The real Ada was aiding Leon and Sherry while destroying the Neo-Umbrella lab in Langshiang. Although presumed dead after being shot by one of Simmons' soldiers, Carla attempts a final attack against Ada, after having injected herself with a powerful dose of the C-virus, but is killed. After aiding Leon and Helena in their battle with Simmons, Ada destroys the lab where her clone was developed, and accepts a new assignment. Leon and Helena are cleared for duty; Chris remains with the BSAA in command of a new squad, overcoming his guilt; Sherry continues her duty as a DSO agent; and Jake starts a new life fighting zombies in an underdeveloped country with his identity covered up by the BSAA.
